tn.text: Jeremiah is speaking to the people of Jerusalem. See:[[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]]
"Hurry around in"

tn.ref: Then look and think about this
tn.text: "look and find out"
Broad and open places in a city where people can gather.

tn.ref: If you can find a man or anyone
tn.text: "Whether you can find one person"
"does what is just"
The word "they" refers to the people of Jerusalem.
People used this phrase when making an solemn oath in order to ask Yahweh to punish them if they broke the oath. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:04:01|4:2]].

tn.ref: do your eyes not look for faithfulness
tn.text: Jeremiah uses this question to emphasize that what Yahweh really wants is faithfulness. AT: "you want people to be faithful." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: You struck the people, but they do not feel pain.
tn.text: AT: "You punish the people, but they do not pay attention." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"have completely destroyed"
"to learn their lesson"

tn.ref: They make their faces harder than rock
tn.text: AT: "They became very stubborn."
Jeremiah is speaking.

tn.ref: But they all broke their yoke together; they all tore apart the chains that bound them to God.
tn.text: The yoke and chains represent the law which bind God and his people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: So a lion ... A wolf ... A lurking panther
tn.text: These are dangerous animals that can kill people. Possible meanings are 1) "Wild animals will come and kill people" or 2) "an enemy army will come and kill people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
a set of bushes that grew closely together.
a wild dangerous dog
"waiting"
a large wild dangerous cat
not able to be counted

tn.ref: Why should I pardon these people
tn.text: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that he has no reason to pardon these people. AT: "Because of the things that they do, I cannot pardon these people." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
the people of Jerusalem
Yahweh is speaking to Jerusalem as though she were a woman who had children. AT: "The people of Jerusalem." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
"I gave them everything they needed."

tn.ref: and took on the marks of a house of prostitution
tn.text: "and went in large groups to the houses of prostitutes"
"that were ready to mate"
when animals breed or lie together to reproduce

tn.ref: Each man neighed to his neighbor's wife
tn.text: Male horses neigh loudly to female horses when they want to sleep with them. AT: "Each man was trying to sleep with his neighbor's wife." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: So should I not punish them ... and should I not avenge myself on a nation that is like this?
tn.text: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that the things that they are doing are so bad that he will no have mercy and stop himself from punishing them. AT: "Because they do these things, I will punish them ... I will certainly get revenge for myself against them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|1:8]].
Yahweh continues to speak.

tn.ref: Go up onto her vineyards' terraces
tn.text: "Get up over her walls." Yahweh is comparing the city of Jerusalem to a vineyard that has a wall around it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Yahweh is speaking to the enemies of people living in Jerusalem.

tn.ref: do not bring complete destruction to them
tn.text: "do not completely destroy them"

tn.ref: Trim their vines, since those vines do not come from Yahweh
tn.text: Yahweh compares how the enemies of Jerusalem will rid of her people to how people cut branches off of a vine. AT: "Get rid of all of the evil people because they do not come from Yahweh."

tn.ref: For the houses of Israel and Judah
tn.text: AT: "For the people of Israel and Judah." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|1:8]].
This could also be translated as, "they have lied about me."
"Yahweh does not exist." This could also be translated as "He will not do these things" or "He cannot do these things"

tn.ref: Evil will not come on us, nor will we see sword or famine
tn.text: These two sentences say the same thing, the second is more specific than the first. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Evil will not come on us
tn.text: This expression means "Bad things will not happen to us."

tn.ref: nor will we see sword or famine
tn.text: AT: "and we will not experience war or famine." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "you" refers to the people of Israel and Judah.
See what the people said in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:05:10|5:12]].
AT: "Look" or "Listen" or "Pay attention to what I am about to tell you"

tn.ref: I am about to place my word in your mouth. It will be like a fire
tn.text: "I am about to make the words that I have you speak for me into a fire"
The word "your" refers to Jeremiah. "for you to speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
the people of Israel

"the fire will burn up the people of Israel" Yahweh's word will destroy the people like a fire burns wood. AT: "Because you will destroy the people of Israel when you speak my words." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"to attack you." The word "you" refers to the people of Israel.
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:02:04|2:4]].

tn.ref: it is a lasting nation, an ancient nation!
tn.text: These phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize how long the nation has existed. AT: "it is a very old and enduring nation!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"an enduring nation" or "a very strong nation"

tn.ref: It is a nation whose language you do not know, nor will you understand what they say
tn.text: The second phrase says in negative terms the same thing that the first phrase says in positive terms. This emphasizes that they do not know the language of the people who live in that nation. AT: "It is a nation whose language you will not understand." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Its quiver is like an open tomb
tn.text: The arrows that come from the quiver kill very many people and send them to their grave. AT: "That nation will use arrow to kill very many people." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
The word "Its" refers to the nation that Yahweh will bring to attack Israel.
a container for holding arrows

tn.ref: So your harvest will be consumed
tn.text: AT: "So the army of that nation will eat what you expected to harvest." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The word "They" refers to the army of that nation.

tn.ref: They will batter down with a sword your fortified cities
tn.text: The sword represents all of the different weapons that people use in war. AT: "They will use their weapons to conquer your strong cities." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"that you thought were strong enough to keep you safe"
The phrase "those days" refers to the time when a distant nation will come and attack the people of Israel.
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|1:8]].
"will not destroy"
"When you" or "When it happens that you"
Yahweh sent a foreign army to attack Israel.
Many versions translate, "served foreign gods," but here what is meant is worshiping them.
Yahweh is speaking to the people of Israel.
"Tell this"
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:02:04|2:4]].

tn.ref: let it be heard in Judah
tn.text: "announce it in Judah"

tn.ref: people! For idols have no will
tn.text: "people that has no mind." AT: "people that cannot understand." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: there are eyes in them, but they cannot see.
tn.text: AT: "You have eyes but you do not understand what I am doing"

tn.ref: There are ears on them, but they do not hear
tn.text: "AT: "You have ears but you do not understand what I am telling you"
See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:01:07|1:8]].

tn.ref: Do you not fear me ... face?
tn.text: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that the people are extremely foolish because they do not fear Yahweh. AT: "It is foolish that you do not fear me ... face!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
AT: "or shake with fear because of me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: I have placed a border of sand against the sea
tn.text: "I placed the sand as the border for the sea"

tn.ref: an ongoing decree that it does not violate
tn.text: "an everlasting limit that it cannot cross"
"tosses back and forth"
AT: "not succeed in overcoming the border." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
Yahweh continues to speak to the people of Israel.
AT: "is stubborn and rebellious." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: It turns away in rebellion and goes away
tn.text: "They turn away and go away." AT: "They do not obey or listen." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: they do not say in their hearts
tn.text: AT: "they do not think to themselves."

tn.ref: keeping the fixed weeks of the harvest for us
tn.text: "and makes sure for us that the weeks of harvest happens when they are supposed to"
The word "Your refers to the descendants of Jacob and the people of Judah. "your sins"
the rains and the harvest
Yahweh continues to speak.

tn.ref: For wicked men are found with my people
tn.text: AT: "For I have found wicked men among my people." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: they set a trap and catch people
tn.text: AT: "They set things up so that they can take advantage of people." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"become powerful and rich"
being** - "and sleek" or "and smooth." The people look smooth because their thick fat hides their bones.

tn.ref: They crossed over all bounds of wickedness
tn.text: "They do things that are even worse than evil."
This refers to court cases in which orphans ask that justice be done. AT: "they do not support the court cases brought by orphans." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: Should I not punish ... a nation like this?
tn.text: See how you translated "So should I not punish ... a nation that is like this?" in [[:en:bible:notes:jer:05:07|5:9]].
Yahweh continues to speak.
"A dreadful and awful thing has occurred"
AT: "in the land of Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"prophesy lies"
"according to the directions of the prophets"

tn.ref: but what will happen in the end
tn.text: "but what will you do at the end of all of this?" Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that the people will regret being wicked when it results in punishment. AT: "but you will be in trouble and regret this wicked behavior when it ends with punishment?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The phrase "the end" refers to the punishment that results from the wicked things that the people have done.
